section.title: Develop Plugins
section.para: This document describes how to write an XJC plugin to extend the code generation of XJC.

section.title: What Can A Plugin Do?
section.para: An XJC plugin participates in the code generation from a schema. It can define its own customizations that users can use to control it, it can access the code that the JAXB RI generates, it can generate additional classes/methods/fields/annotations/comments, and it can also replace some of the pluggability points in the compilation process, such as XML name -> Java name conversion.
As a show case of what a plugin can do, take a look at plugins hosted at JAXB2-commons.

section.title: Quick Start
section.para: To write a plugin, do the following simple steps.

listitem.para: Write a class, say, org.acme.MyPlugin by extending com.sun.tools.xjc.Plugin. See javadoc for how to implement methods.
Write the name of your plugin class in a text file and put it as /META-INF/services/com.sun.tools.xjc.Plugin in your jar file.

section.para: Users can then use your plugins by declaring an XJC ant task with your jar files.

informalexample.programlisting: <taskdef name="xjc" classname="com.sun.tools.xjc.XJCTask"> <classpath> <fileset dir="jaxb-ri/lib" includes="*.jar"/> <fileset dir="your-plugin" includes="*.jar"/> </classpath> </taskdef>
